member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.Revolutions
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of revolutions this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents.

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.Degrees
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of degrees this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents.

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.Minutes
member.summary: Gets or sets the minutes component of the degrees this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents. When setting the minutes, if the value is in the range (-60, 60) the whole degrees are not changed; otherwise, the whole degrees may be changed. Fractional values may set the seconds component.

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.Seconds
member.summary: Gets or sets the seconds of the degrees this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents. When setting the seconds, if the value is in the range (-60, 60) the whole minutes or whole degrees are not changed; otherwise, the whole minutes or whole degrees may be changed.

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.Radians
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of radians this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents.

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.Milliradians
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of milliradians this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents. One milliradian is equal to 1/(2000π).

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.Gradians
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of gradians this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents.

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.IsRight
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is a right angle (i.e. 90° or π/2).

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.IsStraight
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is a straight angle (i.e. 180° or π).

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.IsFullRotation
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is a full rotation angle (i.e. 360° or 2π).

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.IsOblique
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is an oblique angle (i.e. is not 90° or a multiple of 90°).

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.IsAcute
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is an acute angle (i.e. less than 90° but greater than 0°).

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.IsObtuse
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is an obtuse angle (i.e. greater than 90° but less than 180°).

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.IsReflex
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is a reflex angle (i.e. greater than 180° but less than 360°).

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.Complement
member.summary: Gets a SharpDX.AngleSingle instance that complements this angle (i.e. the two angles add to 90°).

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.Supplement
member.summary: Gets a SharpDX.AngleSingle instance that supplements this angle (i.e. the two angles add to 180°).

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.ZeroAngle
member.summary: Gets a new SharpDX.AngleSingle instance that represents the zero angle (i.e. 0°).

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.RightAngle
member.summary: Gets a new SharpDX.AngleSingle instance that represents the right angle (i.e. 90° or π/2).

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.StraightAngle
member.summary: Gets a new SharpDX.AngleSingle instance that represents the straight angle (i.e. 180° or π).

member.name: P:SharpDX.AngleSingle.FullRotationAngle
member.summary: Gets a new SharpDX.AngleSingle instance that represents the full rotation angle (i.e. 360° or 2π).

member.name: M:SharpDX.BoundingFrustum.GetZoomToExtentsShiftDistance(SharpDX.Vector3[])
member.summary: Get the distance which when added to camera position along the lookat direction will do the effect of zoom to extents (zoom to fit) operation, so all the passed points will fit in the current view. if the returned value is positive, the camera will move toward the lookat direction (ZoomIn). if the returned value is negative, the camera will move in the reverse direction of the lookat direction (ZoomOut).

member.name: M:SharpDX.BoundingFrustum.GetZoomToExtentsShiftVector(SharpDX.Vector3[])

member.name: M:SharpDX.Collision.RayIntersectsPoint(SharpDX.Ray@,SharpDX.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a point.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Collision.RayIntersectsRay(SharpDX.Ray@,SharpDX.Ray@,SharpDX.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the point of intersection, or if there was no intersection.
member.remarks: This method performs a ray vs ray intersection test based on the following formula from Goldman. s = det([o_2 - o_1, d_2, d_1 x d_2]) / ||d_1 x d_2||^2 t = det([o_2 - o_1, d_1, d_1 x d_2]) / ||d_1 x d_2||^2 Where o_1 is the position of the first ray, o_2 is the position of the second ray, d_1 is the normalized direction of the first ray, d_2 is the normalized direction of the second ray, det denotes the determinant of a matrix, x denotes the cross product, [ ] denotes a matrix, and || || denotes the length or magnitude of a vector.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Collision.RayIntersectsPlane(SharpDX.Ray@,SharpDX.Plane@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .

member.name: M:SharpDX.Collision.RayIntersectsTriangle(SharpDX.Ray@,SharpDX.Vector3@,SharpDX.Vector3@,SharpDX.Vector3@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a triangle.
member.param: The first vertex of the triangle to test.
The second vertex of the triangle to test.
The third vertex of the triangle to test.
When the method completes, contains the distance of the intersection, or 0 if there was no intersection.
member.remarks: This method tests if the ray intersects either the front or back of the triangle. If the ray is parallel to the triangle's plane, no intersection is assumed to have happened. If the intersection of the ray and the triangle is behind the origin of the ray, no intersection is assumed to have happened. In both cases of assumptions, this method returns false.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Matrix.Transpose
member.summary: Transposes the matrix.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Matrix.Orthogonalize
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified matrix.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the matrix will be orthogonal to any other given row in the matrix.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Matrix.Orthonormalize
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified matrix.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified matrix.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthogonalized matrix.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the matrix will be orthogonal to any other given row in the matrix.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Matrix.UpperTriangularForm(SharpDX.Matrix@,SharpDX.Matrix@)
member.summary: Brings the matrix into upper triangular form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The matrix to put into upper triangular form.
When the method completes, contains the upper triangular matrix.
member.remarks: If the matrix is not invertible (i.e. its determinant is zero) than the result of this method may produce Single.Nan and Single.Inf values. When the matrix represents a system of linear equations, than this often means that either no solution exists or an infinite number of solutions exist.

When the method completes, contains the resultant matrix after the operation.
When the method completes, contains the resultant fifth column of the matrix.

remarks.para: The fifth column is often called the augmented part of the matrix. This is because the fifth column is really just an extension of the matrix so that there is a place to put all of the non-zero components after the operation is complete.
Often times the resultant matrix will the identity matrix or a matrix similar to the identity matrix. Sometimes, however, that is not possible and numbers other than zero and one may appear.

This method can be used to solve systems of linear equations. Upon completion of this method, the will contain the solution for the system. It is up to the user to analyze both the input and the result to determine if a solution really exists.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.summary: Decomposes a Matrix3x3 into an orthonormalized Matrix3x3 Q and a right triangular Matrix3x3 R.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized Matrix3x3 of the decomposition.
When the method completes, contains the right triangular Matrix3x3 of the decomposition.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Matrix3x3.DecomposeLQ(SharpDX.Matrix3x3@,SharpDX.Matrix3x3@)

member.param: When the method completes, contains the lower triangular Matrix3x3 of the decomposition.
When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized Matrix3x3 of the decomposition.

member.param: When the method completes, contains the scaling component of the decomposed Matrix3x3.
When the method completes, contains the rotation component of the decomposed Matrix3x3.
member.remarks: This method is designed to decompose an SRT transformation Matrix3x3 only.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Matrix3x3.DecomposeUniformScale(System.Single@,SharpDX.Quaternion@)
member.summary: Decomposes a uniform scale matrix into a scale, rotation, and translation. A uniform scale matrix has the same scale in every axis.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the scaling component of the decomposed matrix.
When the method completes, contains the rotation component of the decomposed matrix.
member.remarks: This method is designed to decompose only an SRT transformation matrix that has the same scale in every axis.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize(SharpDX.Matrix3x3@,SharpDX.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthogonalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize(SharpDX.Matrix3x3)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize(SharpDX.Matrix3x3@,SharpDX.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize(SharpDX.Matrix3x3)
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Matrix3x3.UpperTriangularForm(SharpDX.Matrix3x3@,SharpDX.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Brings the Matrix3x3 into upper triangular form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The Matrix3x3 to put into upper triangular form.
When the method completes, contains the upper triangular Matrix3x3.
member.remarks: If the Matrix3x3 is not invertible (i.e. its determinant is zero) than the result of this method may produce Single.Nan and Single.Inf values. When the Matrix3x3 represents a system of linear equations, than this often means that either no solution exists or an infinite number of solutions exist.

member.name: T:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox
member.summary: OrientedBoundingBox (OBB) is a rectangular block, much like an AABB (BoundingBox) but with an arbitrary orientation.

member.name: F:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox.Extents
member.summary: Half lengths of the box along each axis.

member.name: F:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox.Transformation
member.summary: The matrix which aligns and scales the box, and its translation vector represents the center of the box.

member.name: M:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox.#ctor(SharpDX.BoundingBox)
member.summary: Creates an from a BoundingBox.
member.remarks: Initially, the OBB is axis-aligned box, but it can be rotated and transformed later.

member.name: M:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox.#ctor(SharpDX.Vector3,SharpDX.Vector3)
member.summary: Creates an which contained between two minimum and maximum points.
member.param: The minimum vertex of the bounding box.
The maximum vertex of the bounding box.
member.remarks: Initially, the OrientedBoundingBox is axis-aligned box, but it can be rotated and transformed later.

member.name: M:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox.#ctor(SharpDX.Vector3[])
member.summary: Creates an that fully contains the given points.
member.param: The points that will be contained by the box.
member.remarks: This method is not for computing the best tight-fitting OrientedBoundingBox. And initially, the OrientedBoundingBox is axis-aligned box, but it can be rotated and transformed later.

member.name: M:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox.GetCorners
member.summary: Retrieves the eight corners of the bounding box.
member.returns: An array of points representing the eight corners of the bounding box.

member.name: M:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox.Transform(SharpDX.Matrix@)
member.summary: Transforms this box using a transformation matrix.
member.remarks: While any kind of transformation can be applied, it is recommended to apply scaling using scale method instead, which scales the Extents and keeps the Transformation matrix for rotation only, and that preserves collision detection accuracy.

member.name: M:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox.Transform(SharpDX.Matrix)
member.summary: Transforms this box using a transformation matrix.
member.remarks: While any kind of transformation can be applied, it is recommended to apply scaling using scale method instead, which scales the Extents and keeps the Transformation matrix for rotation only, and that preserves collision detection accuracy.

member.name: M:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox.Scale(SharpDX.Vector3@)
member.summary: Scales the by scaling its Extents without affecting the Transformation matrix, By keeping Transformation matrix scaling-free, the collision detection methods will be more accurate.

member.name: M:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox.Scale(SharpDX.Vector3)
member.summary: Scales the by scaling its Extents without affecting the Transformation matrix, By keeping Transformation matrix scaling-free, the collision detection methods will be more accurate.

member.name: M:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox.Scale(System.Single)
member.summary: Scales the by scaling its Extents without affecting the Transformation matrix, By keeping Transformation matrix scaling-free, the collision detection methods will be more accurate.

member.summary: Translates the to a new position using a translation vector;

member.name: M:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox.Translate(SharpDX.Vector3)
member.summary: Translates the to a new position using a translation vector;

member.name: M:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox.GetSize
member.summary: Returns the size of the taking into consideration the scaling applied to the transformation matrix.
member.remarks: This method is computationally expensive, so if no scale is applied to the transformation matrix use property instead.

member.name: M:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox.GetSizeSquared
member.summary: Returns the square size of the taking into consideration the scaling applied to the transformation matrix.

member.summary: Determines whether a contains a .
member.param: Optimize the check operation by assuming that has no scaling applied
member.returns: The type of containment the two objects have.
member.remarks: This method is not designed for which has a non-uniform scaling applied to its transformation matrix. But any type of scaling applied using Scale method will keep this method accurate.

member.summary: Check the intersection between two
member.returns: The type of containment the two objects have.
member.remarks: For accuracy, The transformation matrix for both must not have any scaling applied to it. Anyway, scaling using Scale method will keep this method accurate.

The second point in the line.
member.returns: The type of containment the two objects have.

member.name: M:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox.GetBoxToBoxMatrix(SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox@,SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Calculates the matrix required to transfer any point from one local coordinates to another.
member.param: If true, the method will use a fast algorithm which is inapplicable if a scale is applied to the transformation matrix of the OrientedBoundingBox.

member.name: M:SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox.Merge(SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox@,SharpDX.OrientedBoundingBox@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Merge an OrientedBoundingBox B into another OrientedBoundingBox A, by expanding A to contain B and keeping A orientation.
member.param: If true, the method will use a fast algorithm which is inapplicable if a scale is applied to the transformation matrix of the OrientedBoundingBox.
member.remarks: Unlike merging axis aligned boxes, The operation is not interchangeable, because it keeps A orientation and merge B into it.

member.summary: Merge this OrientedBoundingBox into another OrientedBoundingBox, keeping the other OrientedBoundingBox orientation.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Vector2.DistanceSquared(SharpDX.Vector2@,SharpDX.Vector2@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Vector2.DistanceSquared(SharpDX.Vector2,SharpDX.Vector2)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.returns: The squared distance between the two vectors.

For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Vector2.Orthogonalize(SharpDX.Vector2[],SharpDX.Vector2[])
member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthogonalize.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:SharpDX.Vector2.Orthonormalize(SharpDX.Vector2[],SharpDX.Vector2[])
member.summary: Orthonormalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthonormalize.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other and making all vectors of unit length. This means that any given vector will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:SharpDX.Vector2.TransformCoordinate(SharpDX.Vector2@,SharpDX.Matrix@,SharpDX.Vector2@)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Vector2.TransformNormal(SharpDX.Vector2@,SharpDX.Matrix@,SharpDX.Vector2@)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed normal.
member.remarks: A normal transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is zero. This causes the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix to be unused. The end result is a vector that is not translated, but all other transformation properties apply. This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Vector3.DistanceSquared(SharpDX.Vector3@,SharpDX.Vector3@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Vector3.Orthogonalize(SharpDX.Vector3[],SharpDX.Vector3[])
member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthogonalize.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:SharpDX.Vector3.Orthonormalize(SharpDX.Vector3[],SharpDX.Vector3[])
member.summary: Orthonormalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthonormalize.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other and making all vectors of unit length. This means that any given vector will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:SharpDX.Vector3.TransformCoordinate(SharpDX.Vector3@,SharpDX.Matrix@,SharpDX.Vector3@)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Vector3.TransformNormal(SharpDX.Vector3@,SharpDX.Matrix@,SharpDX.Vector3@)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed normal.
member.remarks: A normal transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is zero. This causes the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix to be unused. The end result is a vector that is not translated, but all other transformation properties apply. This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Vector4.DistanceSquared(SharpDX.Vector4@,SharpDX.Vector4@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Vector4.DistanceSquared(SharpDX.Vector4,SharpDX.Vector4)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.returns: The squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Vector4.Orthogonalize(SharpDX.Vector4[],SharpDX.Vector4[])
member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthogonalize.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:SharpDX.Vector4.Orthonormalize(SharpDX.Vector4[],SharpDX.Vector4[])
member.summary: Orthonormalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthonormalize.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other and making all vectors of unit length. This means that any given vector will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .
